docs.abstract: The tragedy of racism is only part of the story in two very different plays from London that carry a dimension of meaning not usually seen in this country.
docs.snippet: The tragedy of racism is only part of the story in two very different plays from London that carry a dimension of meaning not usually seen in this country.
docs.lead_paragraph: As far as theater is concerned, the pandemic has been a paradox, shrinking life down to lockdown bubbles and simultaneously expanding horizons. When you can stream plays from Europe as easily as from Brooklyn, the world seems more interconnected than in the past — tied together by bonds of humanity.

headline.main: Making Black Lives, Not Just Black Deaths, Matter Onstage

docs.abstract: Misguided students believe that defending Harvey Weinstein makes Ronald Sullivan unfit to be their dean. Apparently the university agrees.
docs.snippet: Misguided students believe that defending Harvey Weinstein makes Ronald Sullivan unfit to be their dean. Apparently the university agrees.
docs.lead_paragraph: I have been a professor at Harvard University for 34 years. In that time, the school has made some mistakes. But it has never so thoroughly embarrassed itself as it did this past weekend. At the center of the controversy is Ronald Sullivan, a law professor who ran afoul of student activists enraged that he was willing to represent Harvey Weinstein.

headline.main: Harvard Betrays a Law Professor — and Itself

docs.abstract: A guide to some changes in the curriculum, and how the new course differs from standard treatments of Black history in American high schools.
docs.snippet: A guide to some changes in the curriculum, and how the new course differs from standard treatments of Black history in American high schools.
docs.lead_paragraph: Reparations. Black Lives Matter. Queer studies.

headline.main: Inside the College Board’s Revised African American Studies Curriculum
headline.print_headline: Curriculum Dispenses With Black Lives Matter and Barely Mentions Reparations

docs.abstract: Though the city is recording hundreds of new coronavirus cases each week and some officers have died, many are not heeding instructions to cover their faces.
docs.snippet: Though the city is recording hundreds of new coronavirus cases each week and some officers have died, many are not heeding instructions to cover their faces.
docs.lead_paragraph: Riot helmets, ballistic vests, shields, batons — fully decked-out police officers have become staples in New York City as the protests against racism and police brutality approach their third week. But increasingly, one piece of equipment has attracted attention with its absence: the face mask.

headline.main: Why Are So Many N.Y.P.D. Officers Refusing to Wear Masks at Protests?
headline.print_headline: At New York Protests, Police Wear Protective Gear, but Many Skip Masks

docs.abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
docs.snippet: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
docs.lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline.main: 9 Plays and Musicals to Go to in N.Y.C. This Weekend

docs.abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
docs.snippet: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
docs.lead_paragraph: For this roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to reflect on how their generation is fighting for democracy, to tell us if they have ever grown anything and to muse about if they would take a “flight to nowhere.”

headline.main: What Students Are Saying About Democracy, Caring For Plants and “Flights to Nowhere”

docs.abstract: Would you go to work for this president?
docs.snippet: Would you go to work for this president?
docs.lead_paragraph: After an eruption, volcanoes sometimes collapse at the center. The magma chamber empties out and the volcano falls in on itself, leaving a caldera and a fractured ring of stone around the void, covered by deadening ash.

docs.abstract: Why it’s so difficult to find viable solutions for California’s homelessness crisis.
docs.snippet: Why it’s so difficult to find viable solutions for California’s homelessness crisis.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the last edition of this newsletter, I wrote about the proliferation of tiny-home villages for those living on the streets. Today, I will be focusing on what it is like to live in one and why there are no easy fixes.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Hope of the Valley Rescue Mission

docs.abstract: What makes Mayor Eric Adams of New York hard to pin down is what makes him so interesting.
docs.snippet: What makes Mayor Eric Adams of New York hard to pin down is what makes him so interesting.
docs.lead_paragraph: Many Black Americans have a friend or relative like Eric Adams, the new mayor of New York. We have uncles who bring up the progressive benefits of Black Lives Matter in the same breath as the conservative talking points about Black-on-Black crime. We have relatives who are cops or former cops who do not want the police defunded nor loved ones stopped, frisked and mistreated by officers. We have friends who are deeply suspicious of the system and come up with their own ways to deal with it — in Mr. Adams’s case, proposing that his brother head up his security operation to keep him safe.

headline.main: A Leader Who Defies Easy Political Labeling. Finally.

docs.abstract: HBO Max has temporarily pulled the film from its streaming service after the filmmaker John Ridley called out its “painful stereotypes of people of color.”
docs.snippet: HBO Max has temporarily pulled the film from its streaming service after the filmmaker John Ridley called out its “painful stereotypes of people of color.”
docs.lead_paragraph: When HBO Max went live last month, one of the streaming service’s selling points was its TCM-branded channel of Hollywood classics, including “Citizen Kane,” “Singin’ in the Rain,” “Casablanca” — and “Gone With the Wind,” the Oscar-winning 1939 adaptation of Margaret Mitchell’s novel, and, according to the American Film Institute, the sixth-greatest American movie of all time.

headline.main: ‘Gone With the Wind’ and Controversy: What You Need to Know
